metadata.title: Interval Observer-Based Detection and Localization Against False Data Injection Attack in Smart Grids
metadata.abstract: The cyber security of large-scale smart grid against false data injection attack (FDIA) is concerned in this article. FDIA can modify the sensor data and make internal states cause bias without being detected by the bad data detection system. We propose a method for FDIA detection and localization in the smart grid in this article. First, a series of interval observers are designed by considering the bounds of internal states, modeling errors, and disturbances to estimate the interval states of the grid physical system. By using the interval residuals of interval observers, a detection scheme against FDIA is proposed. For FDIA localization, the measurement data of the corresponding sensor is used as the input of the interval observer. Therefore, each interval observer is responsible for FDIA detection and localization of the corresponding sensor. Furthermore, the logic localization judgment matrix is constructed for localizing the sensor in which FDIA is injected. Then, the detection and localization scheme against FDIA is proposed based on the interval observer and the logic localization judgment matrix. Finally, simulations on the IEEE 36-bus grid are performed to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed interval observer-based FDIA detection and localization algorithm.

grobid.contents:
Interval Observer-Based Detection and Localization Against False Data Injection Attack in Smart Grids
JANUARY 15, 2021

Member, IEEEXiaoyuan Luo 
Yating Li 
Xinyu Wang 
Fellow, IEEEXinping Guan 
Interval Observer-Based Detection and Localization Against False Data Injection Attack in Smart Grids

IEEE INTERNET OF THINGS JOURNAL
82JANUARY 15, 202110.1109/JIOT.2020.3005926657
The cyber security of large-scale smart grid against false data injection attack (FDIA) is concerned in this article. FDIA can modify the sensor data and make internal states cause bias without being detected by the bad data detection system. We propose a method for FDIA detection and localization in the smart grid in this article. First, a series of interval observers are designed by considering the bounds of internal states, modeling errors, and disturbances to estimate the interval states of the grid physical system. By using the interval residuals of interval observers, a detection scheme against FDIA is proposed. For FDIA localization, the measurement data of the corresponding sensor is used as the input of the interval observer. Therefore, each interval observer is responsible for FDIA detection and localization of the corresponding sensor. Furthermore, the logic localization judgment matrix is constructed for localizing the sensor in which FDIA is injected. Then, the detection and localization scheme against FDIA is proposed based on the interval observer and the logic localization judgment matrix. Finally, simulations on the IEEE 36-bus grid are performed to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed interval observer-based FDIA detection and localization algorithm.Index Terms-False data injection attack (FDIA), interval observer, logic localization judgment matrix, smart grid.

exploit the covert channel [6]. Some attacks can be launched from specific smart grid protocols such as OCPP [7]. For the problems of defense against attack and the efficient restoration, in [8], a network infrastructure based on three layers, where the redundant support is primarily concentrated on a fog-based structure to protect a specific subset of cyber-physical control device, is presented. Alcaraz and Wolthusen [9] studied the efficient restoration strategy of controllability following attack and the attacker-defender interaction in the power-law network, and proposed three repair strategies for controllability in control graphs by using the structural controllability abstraction. These potential cyber-physical threats have caused some large-area power grid paralysis. In the United Kingdom, for example, blackouts affected one million homes and caused power outages across England and Wales, an unexpected power outage to generators in August, 2019 [10]; on December 23, 2015, Ukrainian power companies experienced unscheduled power outages, which impacted 225 000 customers in Ukraine [11]; and a power outage in March, 2019 plunged more than half of Brazilian states into darkness [12]. As a typical static stealth attack, false data injection attack (FDIA) is first developed in 2009 by Liu et al. [13]. FDIA can be injected in a sensor to destroy the system without being detected. It can circumvent bad data detection (BDD), and stealthily inject any bias into the value of the estimated state. In addition, it has shown that undetectable false data injected attack can be made even if the attacker knows limited resource [14]- [19]. Some scholars have found that the attacker of FDIA can approximate the system state by measuring the amount of power injected [20]. FDIA detection is reformulated as a matrix separation problem in [21]. In [22], the vulnerability of distribution system-state estimation against FDIA is investigated. From the above studies, it has shown that FDIA can destroy the system without being detected. Therefore, FDIA, as a kind of static stealth attack, is widely recognized to be a cyber attack on the smart grid. If FDIA is well coordinated with physical attack, line outage initiated by the physical attack could be masked. Therefore, the study of detection and localization against FDIA is of great significance to the cyber security of the smart grid.


A. Related Works on FDIA

In recent years, more and more attention has been paid on cyber attack detection of the smart grid. In general, there are two categories of attack detection methods for the smart grid. One is the Kalman filter (KF)-based detection method [16], [17]- [24] and the other is observer-based detection method [25]- [31]. KF-based detection method has the characteristic of computation simply, therefore, it is widely used for attack detection in the smart grid. Nevertheless, the estimation accuracy of the KF-based detection method is limited by its own characteristics. In [25], it has shown that although FDIA can modify the sensor data without being detected by the BDD system, the effect on the internal state cannot be hidden. Therefore, a set of observers is presented in [25] to detect the FDIA based on the internally physical dynamics by taking the stealthy characteristics of FDIA into account. Based on the observation of internally physical state, some observer-based detection methods are proposed in [26]- [28]. In [29], a decentralized unknown input observerbased attack detection via information from the PMU network is designed for a large-scale smart grid. In [30], a distributed robust detection method based on an observer was developed to detect the FDIA. Considering the stealthy characteristics of FDIA, Luo et al. [25] and Li et al. [31] designed adaptive threshold instead of the precomputed threshold to avoid missing detection. However, the process of threshold design is complex and it is easy to cause calculation error. Furthermore, detection schemes in [25] and [31] did not consider the error caused by interconnection. Two adaptive sliding mode observers were designed in [28] with online parameter estimation to estimate the state attack and sensor attack, respectively. However, the threshold in [28] is not given. In [32], an observer-based attack detection scheme was presented. It can trace deviation from nominal smart grid operation and address the need for an estimation methodology of the nonlinear system such as power network.

However, the effectiveness of the detection methods in [26]- [32] is limited to the computation of the detection threshold. Meanwhile, it may have a higher rate of false alarm due to the calculation error of the threshold. To address this problem, an interval observer is proposed without the computation of the threshold. The standard interval observer is originally presented in [33]. In recent years, scholars have acquired some achievements for interval observer design, e.g., [19] and [34]. A distributed attack detection and secure estimation against the FDIA based on interval observer, by considering the effect of the FDIA on the CPS, was proposed in [19]. In [34], the interval residuals were used to address the limitation of the precomputed threshold and replace the evaluation function and detection threshold used in traditional attack detection methods.

Generally speaking, the above studies in [26]- [34] only considered FDIA detection, the FDIA localization was not been considered. Presently, there are only several studies have proposed FDIA localization methods. In [35], a diagnostic reasoning decision logic method was proposed for isolating the fault sensors by designing a multiple sensor fault signature matrix. An attack signature logic judgment matrix was used in [34] to isolate the generator injected FDIA. However, the localization method in [34] and [35] with multiple sensor fault signature matrix is too complex.

Although the observer-based and interval observer-based detection methods improve the detection performance against FDIA to a certain extent, current detection methods are still facing enormous challenges to the FDIA as follows. To detect and locate FDIA in time, there are some challenges to be addressed: 1) how to address the limitation of the precomputed threshold? 2) how to ensure detection performance with modeling uncertainty? and 3) how to accurately locate the sensor in which false data attack is injected?


B. Contributions and Organization

This article presents a method to detect and locate FDIA by designing a series of interval observers. The convergence conditions of the designed interval observers are given by considering model uncertainties and noises in the smart grid system. The proposed detection and localization scheme includes two steps: 1) global detection and 2) localization. In the global detection step, we propose a global FDIA detection method based on the designed interval observers. According to the interval residuals of all subsystems, the control center can judge which subsystem is injected by FDIA. In the localization step, corresponding sensor measurement data are used as the input of the interval observer. Therefore, each interval observer is responsible for detecting and localizing FDIA for the corresponding sensor. Furthermore, a logic localization judgment matrix is constructed for localizing the sensor in which FDIA is injected. Finally, simulations for an IEEE 36-bus grid are shown to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed interval observer-based detection and localization algorithm against FDIA.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. Section II presents the state-space model and the description of FDIA. Section III illustrates the design of an interval observer for FDIA detection. To locate FDIA, the logic judgment matrix-based algorithm for attack detection and localization is proposed. The simulation experiments are provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed detection and localization algorithm in Section IV. Finally, Section V presents the conclusion.


II. PROBLEM FORMULATION AND PRELIMINARIES

In this section, we first establish the physical dynamic grid model. The stealthy characteristics of FDIA are introduced. Then, the addressing detection and localization problem of FDIA is formulated. Table I summarizes the notations used in this article.

B. False Data Injection Attack

In general, the covert FDIA can bypass the traditional detection mechanism and inject false data into the system without being detected. Thus, it can damage the normal operation of the smart grid system. In this article, we focus on one typical FDIA which aims at tampering with the running state of the generator. The stealthy characteristics of the FDIA are presented as follows.


1) Smart Grid System Static-State Estimation:

Normally, the static-state estimation (SE) for the smart grid system uses the data measured by the supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) system. SCADA sends control instruction to the physical facility through the communication channel. The attacker can falsify sensor data through network invasion technology. Traditional attacks can be detected by BDD technology based on smart grid SE. But FDIA can destroy the system without being detected by SE. The following shows the stealthy of FDIA.

For a smart grid system, the measured output can be expressed as follows:
z = [z 1 , z 2 , . . . , z m ] T = x + d, d ∼ N(0, e )(10)
where ∈ R m * n is the Jacobian matrix. It is supposed that the noise d in (10) is independent, thus the covariance matrix R is a diagonal matrix. The system static SE problem can be solved by weighted least square estimator as follows:x
= T R −1 −1 T R −1 z.
Then, the estimator of measurementẑ is written aŝ
z = x = T R −1 −1 T R −1 z = Kz with K = ( T R −1 ) −1 T R −1 .
Consequently, the residual of the measurement is defined as
r = z −ẑ = (I − K)( x + d) = (I − K)d.
Since the square of L 2 norm r 2 2 follows χ 2 distribution with the degree of freedom m − n, χ 2 -test can be applied on the measurement residual r for BDD. The judgment criteria is as follows:
r 2 2 > κ 2 bad data r 2 2 ≤ κ 2 no bad data.
If r 2 2 > κ 2 , then the bad data might exist, where κ is the judging threshold determined by a hypothesis test P{ r 2 2 > κ 2 } = α with a significant level α [21].

2) False Data Injection Attack: Fig. 2 illustrates the attack strategy of FDIA in the smart grid system. The attacker can spy and modify the sensor measurement data. Then, the attacker can design and inject a bank of special attack vector a = [a 1 , a 2 , . . . , a m ] T into the sensor to modify the data of control flow on the actuator unit [13]. The deviation of the state variable caused by a is denoted as c [32]. Then, the measurement and its estimation are as z bad = z + a and z bad = x bad = (x + c), respectively, where z bad is the malicious measurement andx bad is SE under FDIA. The residual r 2 in this situation is as follows: Obviously, when a = c, the following holds:
r 2 = z bad − x bad 2 = z + a − x + c 2 = z − x + a − c 2 . (11) (a) (b)r 2 = z bad − x bad 2 = z − x 2 .(12)
This means that the attack vector alters the state variable from x to x+c successfully without changing the measurement residual. If FDIA is not detected in time, the influence may even spread to other positions and cause a power blackout.

It has shown that the FDIA can be injected into the measurement of the sensor. It means that the attack vector f is injected in the sensor output y (k) . Then, we can get
y (k) = C (k) x (k) + f , where C (k)
is the output matrix. The sensors are usually placed in generator buses [36]. In the following, we use an example to show the covert of FDIA.

Example 1: To show the stealthy of FDIA, we use a typical smart grid with three generators and six load buses, as shown in Fig. 3, as an example. The parameters of the smart grid system are obtained from [38]. The FDIA is injected in generator G 3 . The simulation results are shown in Fig. 4, in which the FDIA is launched starting at time 15 s, the duration of the attack T ∈ [15, +∞), and the attack sequence is obtained from [18]  r a (t) − r(t). r a (t) is the residual when the system is under attack and r(t) is the residual without attack. As shown in Fig. 4(a), while FDIA starts to modify sensor measurement data serially, the estimated state begins to deviate from the actual state. However, it can be seen from Fig. 4(b) that the χ 2 -test cannot detect the attack. It proves the covert of FDIA from the above analysis results.

As the sensors are placed on generators, and the measurements of sensors are the frequency of generators. The generator's over-frequency relays trip at 62 Hz and the underfrequency relays trip at 58 Hz [38]. Therefore, the measurements y (k) of sensors have a limitation. The upper and lower limitations without FDIA are
y (k) min = 1 y (k) max = 2(14)

Therefore, the main work of this article is to detect and locate FDIA before the output is out of the limitation and to keep the system from being seriously damaged.


C. Problem Formulation

From the above analysis, we can obtain that BDD is incapable of FDIA detection. Therefore, the purposes of this article are shown as follows: 1) design interval observer by considering unknown disturbance and uncertainty parameter and give convergence condition to obtain the interval of state of the system and 2) achieve the FDIA detection and localization based on the designed interval observer, by constructing the logical judgment matrix.


III. INTERVAL OBSERVER DESIGN FOR SMART GRID

In this section, the interval observer is designed for the detection of FDIA with model (7) in Section II, and the convergence conditions of the designed interval observer without FDIA are given.

In the previous section, it has stated that the sensor measurements are generator' frequencies. The generator frequencies are always a fixed value without attack. Therefore, we use the special sensor measurements as the interval observer input for the later location. The input of ith interval observer is y (k|i) (t) = (k|i) y (k) (t) where the corner mark (k|i) is used to denote the index of ith interval observer and (k|i) is the selection matrix. The sensor output and the parameter matrices F (k|i) , W (k|i) , T (k|i) , and H (k|i) are used to constitute the interval observers. Let x (k|i) (t) and x (k|i) (t) be the estimate of the system state x (k) (t) by using the sensor output y (k|i) (t),
y (k|i) (t) = (k|i) C (k) x (k) (t) =C (k|i) x (k) (t).

IV. INTERVAL OBSERVER-BASED DETECTION AND LOCALIZATION AGAINST FDIA

For large-scale smart grids, attack detection and localization are both crucial problems. First, the interval observers are designed with considering the bounds of internal state, modeling error, and disturbance to estimate the interval state of the physical system. On this basis, a detection scheme is proposed to detect FDIA. For FDIA localization, the corresponding sensor data are used as the input of the interval observer. Therefore, each interval observer is responsible for FDIA detection and localization of the corresponding sensor. The main design process for attack detection and localization scheme is shown as follows.


A. Detection Criteria Against FDIA

From the designed interval observer (15), we can get the upper and lower residuals denoted by r (k|i) and r (k|i)
r (k|i) = y (k|i) − y (k|i) r (k|i) = y (k|i) − y (k|i) .(19)
An advantage of the interval observer is that it is not necessary to design the threshold to judge whether there exists cyber attack injected in system from (19).

The judgment criteria is shown as follows:
r (k|i) ≤ 0 ≤ r (k|i)
, no FDIA and denoted by 1 r (k|i) < 0 or 0 < r (k|i) , FDIA and denoted by 0.

From the criteria, once zero is not between r (k|i) and r (k|i) , one can judge that FDIA is injected into the system.


B. Localization Algorithm Based on Logic Localization Judgment Matrix

In Section IV-A, it has shown the FDIA detection. Furthermore, we aim to find the sensor in which FDIA is injected. First, all of the sensor measurements are used for global FDIA detection to find which subsystem is destroyed, as shown in Fig. 5. Next, the sensor in which FDIA is injected should be located. The sensors are divided into two groups by dichotomy. For the two groups, we take the FDIA detection. This location scheme is shown in Fig. 5. To locate the affected sensor, the logic localization judgment matrix is proposed and constructed. Based on the logic localization judgment matrix , a localization algorithm is proposed.


1) Construction of Logic Localization Matrix :

The construction process of the logic localization judgment matrix is shown in Fig. 5. The number of columns in equals to the number of total sensors in the subsystem. The title of each column is the code name of the corresponding sensor. Similarly, the number of rows of equals to n−1. The title of each row is established by dichotomy. The detailed process is shown as follows.

Step 1: The sensors in the subsystem should be divided into two groups, and the first group includes the former (n/2) sensors, the rest of the sensors are included in another group. Therefore, the title of first row is (1, 2, . . . , [n/2])|([n/2] + 1, (n/2) + 1, . . . , n). Then, this step is circulated until each group has only one sensor, as shown in Table II.

Step 2: Based on the result of step 1, the logic localization judgment matrix is established in this step. Match the ith row title with the jth column title, respectively, i = 1, 2, . . . , n − 1, j = 1, 2, . . . , n. If the jth column title is included in the set that the ith row title denotes, the element Remark 4: It is considered in this article that there may exist multiple FDIAs in the system at the same time. That the sensor j is injected into FDIA does not mean that other sensor is not injected into FDIA. Therefore, if sensor j is not included in the set that the ith row title denotes, the element of the ith row and jth column is denoted by X. Later, the logic localization matrix will be matched with the detection vector D created in the next part. Element X in the logic localization judgment matrix can be matched with 1 or 0 in the detection vector D created in the next section. This process is shown in Algorithm 1, in detail.

2) Localization Against FDIA: Based on the logic localization judgment matrix , the localization process is shown as follows.

Step 1: Create the detection vector D. Based on the designed interval observer, take FDIA detection for the divided sensors groups. As shown in (20), if the result is that there exists FDIA, it is denoted by 1. If FDIA is not found in a sensor group, the further division can be omitted. The omitted groups are denoted by /. The detection result is put in the detection vector D.

Step 2: It involves FDIA localization. Match the detection vector D with the columns of logic localization matrix . The element X in the logic localization judgment matrix can be matched with element 1 or 0 in the detection vector D. If the detection vector D can match a row of logic localization judgment matrix , one can judge that the corresponding sensor is affected by FDIAs. This process is shown in Algorithm 1, in detail.


V. SIMULATION

In this section, a simulation on the grid system with 14 generators and 36 buses is studied to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed detection and localization method against FDIA in a smart grid based on interval observer. The simulation software is MATLAB. The essential parameters of the simulation are as follows: the min and max values of uncertainty coefficients are min = 0.8 and max = 1.5; the attack sequence is given by (13).


A. Detection of FDIA

The scale of the grid system with 14 generators and 36 buses, shown in Fig. 1, is too large to make the FDIA detection and localization difficult. To solve this problem, the topology structure-based region division by using the method in [36] is applied to divide the grid system into three subsystems as shown in Fig. 1.

FDIA is launched at time 15 s, the duration of the attack T ∈ [15, +∞). Fig. 6(a) shows the simulation results under the FDIA by using χ 2 -detector and the KF-based detection methods proposed in [18], respectively. When the FDIA is injected into the system, the residual under χ 2 -detector does not exceed the threshold. This means that χ 2 -detector cannot detect the FDIA. Fig. 6(b) shows the comparison between the KF in [18] and the proposed interval observer. One can easily see that the detection delay time under the KF in [18] is bigger than that under the proposed interval observer.

To better illustrate the superiority of the designed interval observer, here we adopt the detection delay and the rate of  a false alarm as the evaluation indexes from the statistic. Simulated program with different disturbances and unknown parameters has been run 5000 times. The simulation results are shown in Fig. 7. Fig. 7(a) and Fig. 7(b) is the detection delays against FDIA under the KF in [18] and the proposed interval observer, respectively. The detection delay that is smaller than 0 means false alarm. We can see in Fig. 7(a) that the delays under the KF in [18] focus mainly around 2.6 s. The delays under the proposed interval observer focus mainly around 1.1 s, as shown in Fig. 7(b). The average detection delay under the KF in [18] is 2.6541 s, while the average detection delay of the proposed interval observer is 1.1165 s. The rates of false alarms for the KF in [18] and the proposed interval observer are counted and shown in Table III, respectively. While the detection times are only 100 times, the times of false alarms under the interval observer are 0, but for the KF, it is one time. It can be seen in Table III that the rate of false alarms under the KF in [18] with 5000 detection times is 0.44%. But under the proposed interval observer, it is 0.16%. The rate of false alarms is reduced a lot due to the redundancy of the threshold.

It is obvious for the FDIA detection that the designed interval observer-based method has a better performance than the KF-based method in [18].

Next, we study the effectiveness of the attack detection algorithm based on interval observer. The example of the localization algorithm based on interval observer is given. The simulation results of all the three subsystems are shown in Fig. 8. Fig. 8(a) shows that zero is not between the upper and lower residuals of the designed interval observer in subsystem 1. As the judgment criteria in (20), subsystem 1 is affected by FDIA. Fig. 8(b) and (c) shows the upper and lower residuals of designed interval observer for subsystems 2 and 3, respectively, and zero is within the upper and lower residuals all the time. Based on judgment criteria in (20), we can get that subsystems 2 and 3 are not affected by FDIA. Thus, the next is to locate the sensors injected into FDIA for subsystem 1 by constructing the logic localization judgment matrix.

C. Discussion

For an attacker, multiple attacks at once are just a special case. In most situations, multiple attacks may not occur simultaneously. Therefore, the detection and localization of multiple attacks that do not happen at the same time are analyzed here.

The interval observer, which is responsible for global detection, works continuously during system operation. The global detection observer can know whether the attack signal of the system is excluded or not. Considering that multiple attack signals do not occur at the same time, the part with a result of 0 in local detection still works until all attack signals are excluded.

Suppose two false data attacks are injected in sensors 1 and 3, respectively. The false data attack in sensor 1 is injected after 10 s, while the false data in sensor 3 is injected after 20 s. The localization result is shown in Fig. 12. The detection  vector at 10 s can only localize the false data attack in sensor 1 since there is no attack in sensor 3 at this point. After 20 s, the detection vector at 20 s can localize the false data both in sensors 1 and 3. In this way, the remaining attack signals can be detected and located even after the local location detection has begun.

VI. CONCLUSION

In this article, the cyber security of a large-scale smart grid against FDIA is concerned. First, the physical dynamics of the smart grid with FDIA are modeled by a mathematical model, and the stealthy characteristics of FDIA are analyzed. Then, the interval observer is designed instead of the ordinary observer by considering the bounds of internal state, modeling error, and disturbance to estimate the interval state of the physical system, and the convergence conditions of the proposed interval observer are given. For FDIA localization, the logic localization judgment matrix is constructed for localizing the sensor which is injected into FDIA. Furthermore, the detection and localization scheme of FDIA is proposed by using the proposed interval observer and the constructed logic localization judgment matrix. Finally, simulations on IEEE 36-bus grid are performed to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed interval observer and FDIA detection and localization algorithm.

Future work of this article will consider the following aspects. The nonlinear part of the model will be analyzed. The defence of the malicious attack in the smart grid will be considered.
